## Other Disorders: Down's syndrome
I found many children with [Down's Syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Down_syndrome). These individuals have their own distinctive facial characteristics related to the chromosonal abnomality, and thus do not provide any information about the facial morphology of children with Autism.
source.e43c78d4:
## Other disorders/syndromes
I also found other children with atypical craniofacial characteristics that would dilute the ability of the algorithms to learn about the facial morphology of autism specifically.
source.47f49767:
## Highly photoshopped photos
Images that have been highly photoshopped may have had the facial characterstics of the children altered to make them more asthetically pleasing, for example, making the face totally symmetrical. Some of the children's photos below fall into the [uncanny valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncanny_valley) due to the heavy amount of processing. By altering the facial characteristics, the deep learning algorithms will not be presented with true facial proportions.
source.e824dc6f: # Concerns with the "Detect Autism from a facial image" dataset
source.1645bce1: ## Background: In the [introduction](https://www.kaggle.com/gpiosenka/autistic-children-data-set-traintestvalidate), the dataset author states that he is interested in the relationship between facial morphology and Autism, specifically in children. He thus constructed a dataset with "autistic" and "non autistic" children to be able to perform a classification task. He gathered 2536 training images, 200 test images, and 100 validation images of size 224 X 224 X 3. It is obvious that the dataset author put a lot of time and care into creating this dataset. He independently collected images from the web for the "autistic" and "non-autistic" categories, and processed them to be of a consistent size and facial alignment. If this kernel helps you to understand this dataset, please give me an upvote!
source.349dfc77:
## Autistic: Smile with grimacing
The dataset creator focused on images of children smiling. Many of the children in the "autistic" category produced a smile with lots of teeth and facial grimacing. While this type of smile may be more frequent children with Autism, it is misleading in this dataset because it encourages the algorithms to find a type of smile as opposed to facial characteristics.
source.e3a365ed: # Summary While I commend the dataset creator on collecting this many images, I worry that inconsistencies across the categories will cause the deep learning algorithms to find differences that are unrelated to facial characteristics in Autism. For some suggestions on how to pivot this reasearch, [see my forum post here.](https://www.kaggle.com/gpiosenka/autistic-children-data-set-traintestvalidate/discussion/208528) If this kernel helped you to understand this dataset, please give me an upvote!
source.4ec96963:
# Presenting concerns

Throughout the dataset, I found inconsistencies and subgroups that may affect a deep learning algorithm's ability to use the facial morphology of children to categorize the images.
- Highly photoshopped images
- Varied facial expressions
- Other disorders
    - Down's syndrome
    - Fragile X
- Babies and adults
source.f5382cfd:
## Other Disorders: Fragile X
I also found a large collection of individuals that appeared to have [Fragile X](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fragile_X_syndrome) syndrome. Two characteristics of Fragile X are prominent ears, and a thin uppper lip. While these individuals can show characteristics of Autism, it is a distinct syndrome with a specific genetic cause.
source.2bc9ef77:
## Varied ages: adults and babies
Some of the images in the "autistic" category appeared to be of adults, or very young babies. Given that adults and children have different facial proportions, I think the algorithms would struggle to find an Autism facial phenotype.
source.016c9277:
## Varied expressions from the "non autistic" category
The  variety of facial expressions may obscure the facial morphology characteristics.
